moves.1. e4 c5 2. d4: The Smith-Morra. One of several playable openings against the Sicilian. Though, from experience, I can tell you that it is probably not the best option. The main line leaves white a pawn down for rapid development and center control, which can effectively take down weaker players and players that do not often play the Smith-Morra. Fortunately, I have played several games with this opening; both using it and against it, so I have a knowledge of how to catch up to the opponent before he or she launches a powerful attack.
moves.2... cxd4 3. c3 dxc3 4. Nxc3: This is the main line and you can see how my opponent may move all of his or her pieces out  into a good position, excluding the rooks, leading to a rapid development.
moves.4... Nc6 5. Nf3 e6 6. Bc4: Typical move set, that really isn't offensive enough. I think these moves are a bit too passive, but perhaps it is because I play too much offensively based games.
moves.6... Nf6 7. Qe2: Passively setting up for a little coup de grace for my minor pieces.
moves.7... Bc5 8. Bg5 Qa5: It's not a good one at that, though.
moves.9. Bxf6 gxf6 10. O-O Qc7: I believe this is pretty useless, but all the other moves are just as adequate.
moves.11. Rac1: I don't understand this move either. It sets up only a poor attack. Rad1 seemed a better move.
moves.11... Qf4 12. Bb3 O-O: Castling into vulnerable space usually is a horrible choice, but in this case it sets a good offensive and an attack on the king is unattainable at the moment, but regardless, it may be a weakness in the endgame.
moves.13. g3 Qg4 14. Kg2 Qg7 15. Nb5 d6 16. Rf: I am puzzled by what this is supposed to accomplish.
moves.17... Rb8 18. Ba2 a5 19. Nd2: My opponent seems to have a bit of problem with his knights.
moves.19... b6 20. Nc4 Ba6 21. Ncxd6: ? This is a mistake at the least. My opponent loses at least 2 points in material.
moves.21... Nd4 22. Rxd4: This loses less than the alternative, which is to lose a knight.
moves.22... Bxd4 23. Qf3: This is another mistake, losing a pawn. It seems my opponent is starting to slip.
moves.23... Bxb2 24. Rc7: Trying to force down my defense and attack my king and queen.
moves.25... Qg5 26. a4 Be5 27. Ra7 Rd2: Slowly setting up an attack against White King, while also threatening several minor pieces in the meantime. It's a good strategy, but you have to make sure your opponent does not strike first.
moves.28. h4: This move isn't necessarily good, as it lowers defense with the king, but it does make the rook vulnerable.
moves.28... Qg6 29. Bb3 Rbd8 30. Bc4 Rc8 31. B: Okay, I get this was a mistake, but I was not going into a draw by repetition .
moves.33. Nxd4 Rd8xd4 34. Bb5 Qxe4: I was able to snag a extra pawn off the exchange, though.
moves.35. Rb7 Qg6 36. Be8: This move really screwed him up. A dangerous gamble, that though at first glance it looks like a good move, it is actually a move that loses pretty badly.
moves.36... Rd4d3: Now noticing that the line ahead of him, which is Bxf7+, loses a bishop, my opponent starts stalling the timer.
moves.37. Qf4: Hoping this can save him, he goes for a desperate attempt of saving his queen.
moves.37... e5: Still desperate for the game not to go any worse, my opponent is about to make a fatal blunder
moves.38. Qc4: Thinking that he has outplayed me and I lost my queen, he confidently plays this move. What he doesn't see is his mistake, which leads to...
moves.38... Qxg3+: 0-1. In the process of saving his queen, my opponent subsequently lets the king die for her.

gameName: The Women Throws the Man into the Fire
